Subject: Religion and Society
ContentHeader: Unit 1: The role of religion in society

Subject: Religion and Society
ContentHeader: Unit 1: The role of religion in society
ContentDescription: In this unit students explore the spiritual origins of religion and understand its role in the development of society, identifying the nature and purpose of religion over time. They investigate religion, including the totality of phenomena to which the term 'religion' refers, and acknowledge religion's contribution to the development of human society. They also focus on the role of spiritualities, religious traditions and religious denominations in shaping personal and group identity over time. Students examine how individuals, groups and new ideas have affected and continue to affect spiritualities, religious traditions and religious denominations. The unit provides an opportunity for students to understand the often complex relationships that exist between individuals, groups, new ideas, truth narratives, spiritualities and religious traditions broadly and in the Australian society in which they live.

Subject: Religion and Society
ContentHeader: Unit 1: The role of religion in society
ContentDescription: A range of examples is studied throughout the unit. For all areas of study, students explore detailed examples from more than one spirituality, religious tradition or religious denomination. These may be from one or more of the groups below. In addition, for Areas of Study 1 and 2 further shorter illustrative examples should be selected for study from across all the groups below:

Subject: Religion and Society
ContentHeader: Unit 1: The role of religion in society
ContentDescription: Spiritualities of First Nations peoples (such as in Australia and Oceania; Africa; Canada and the rest of the Americas; Siberia and the rest of Russia; Scandinavia)

Subject: Religion and Society
ContentHeader: Unit 1: The role of religion in society
ContentDescription: Spiritual and religious ideas in prehistory (associated with, for example, hunter-gatherer societies, Çatalhöyük, Göbekli Tepe, Jericho, Lascaux, Stonehenge)

Subject: Religion and Society
ContentHeader: Unit 1: The role of religion in society
ContentDescription: Religious traditions of ancient civilisations and empires (such as Babylonia, Canaan, Ancient China, Ancient Egypt, the Indus Valley civilisation, Ancient Rome, Sumer)

Subject: Religion and Society
ContentHeader: Unit 1: The role of religion in society
ContentDescription: Asian religious and philosophical traditions (such as Buddhism, Confucianism, Hinduism, Jainism, Shintoism, Sikhism, Taoism)

Subject: Religion and Society
ContentHeader: Unit 1: The role of religion in society
ContentDescription: Abrahamic religions (such as the Bahaʼi Faith, Christianity, Islam, Judaism).

Subject: Religion and Society
ContentHeader: Unit 1: The role of religion in society
ContentDescription: Students consider the aspects of religion on page 10 when investigating selected spiritualities, religious traditions and religion in general.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The nature and purpose of religion
ContentHeader: The nature and purpose of religion
ContentDescription: In this area of study students are introduced to the nature and purpose of religion in general, exploring the role of religion in shaping and giving meaning to individuals and communities.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The nature and purpose of religion
ContentHeader: The nature and purpose of religion
Elaboration: Religion has often been drawn on to provide explanations for all phenomena, offering a means for finding answers to the big questions of life and answering such questions.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The nature and purpose of religion
ContentHeader: The nature and purpose of religion
Elaboration: Students examine the aspects of religion in general, and then apply the aspects of religion as a framework to further examine spiritualities, religious traditions and religious denominations.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The nature and purpose of religion
ContentHeader: The nature and purpose of religion
Elaboration: They also study the interrelation of these aspects generally, and apply the aspects to spiritualities, religious traditions and religious denominations studied.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The nature and purpose of religion
ContentHeader: The nature and purpose of religion
Elaboration: They investigate how the aspects may vary between spiritualities, religious traditions and religious denominations.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The nature and purpose of religion
ContentHeader: The nature and purpose of religion
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to discuss the nature and purpose of religion and examine the aspects of religion as they apply to selected examples.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The nature and purpose of religion
ContentHeader: The nature and purpose of religion
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 1.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Religion through the ages
ContentDescription: In this area of study students investigate how society and religion influence each other.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Religion through the ages
Elaboration: They consider the factors that influence the roles of religion and the effects that developments in society might have on religion.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Religion through the ages
ContentDescription: Spirituality and religion have been an integral part of the development of human societies, forming part of cultural knowledge and understanding that is passed from generation to generation through a process of spiritual and religious socialisation.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Religion through the ages
Elaboration: As people spread across the globe, they encountered and exchanged religious and cultural ideas, which informed the development of aspects of religion.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Religion through the ages
Elaboration: Over time, spiritualities, religious traditions and religious denominations have encountered challenges from philosophical and spiritual movements, political regimes, legal structures, scientific ideas, colonisation, national myths, globalisation, secularisation, technological developments and historical events.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Religion through the ages
Elaboration: These encounters have led to spiritualities, religious traditions and religious denominations taking various roles to initiate, endorse, modify or resist the spread of ideas and movements in society.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Religion through the ages
ContentDescription: At times in history some spiritualities, religious traditions and religious denominations have lost the authority and power to explain meaning for their society and have been abandoned; other spiritualities, religious traditions and religious denominations have adapted and been resilient or were re-established in a different form.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Religion through the ages
Elaboration: Some spiritualities, religious traditions and religious denominations have been able to adopt and adapt beliefs, ideas and practices from other religious traditions while retaining their distinctiveness.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Religion through the ages
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to discuss the changing roles of religion and the interrelationship between religion and society over time.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Religion through the ages
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 2.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Religion in Australia
ContentDescription: In this area of study students consider spiritualities and religion in Australia, past and present, and the influences on Australian religious composition, in particular from colonisation, migration and secularisation.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Religion in Australia
Elaboration: They explore how the communities and later institutions of these spiritualities, religious traditions and religious denominations perceived themselves and expressed their collective identity in Australia.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Religion in Australia
Elaboration: This expression of collective identity may have been cohesive or diverse.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Religion in Australia
Elaboration:
Students also examine the influence 
of religion on the personal identity of members, who may adopt religious ideas or practices from other spiritualities, religious traditions and religious denominations.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Religion in Australia
Elaboration: They explore the influence of spiritualities, religious traditions and religious denominations on the development of social infrastructure in Australia, and consider factors such as the laws governing the provision of education and welfare.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Religion in Australia
Elaboration: This exploration should include the interfaith and ecumenical initiatives between and within spiritualities, religious traditions and religious denominations in Australia and trends of religious adherence in Australia.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Religion in Australia
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to discuss the presence of religion in Australia, past and present.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Religion in Australia
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 3.

Subject: Religion and Society
ContentDescription:
How do we know what is good? How do we make decisions in situations where it is unclear what is good
or not good? Do we accept what society defines as good? Do we do what feels right? Or do we rely on a definition of what is good from a spirituality, religious tradition or religious denomination? What are the principles that guide decision-making? Ethics is concerned with discovering the perspectives that guide practical moral judgment. Studying ethics involves identifying the arguments and analysing the reasoning, and any other influences, behind these perspectives and moral judgments. An important influence on ethical perspective is the method of ethical decision-making, made up of concepts, principles and theories.

Subject: Religion and Society
ContentDescription: Ethical questions that demand practical moral judgment are raised at the personal, family, local, wider community, national and global level. Family, community and traditional connections tie people together and provide an ethical background to guide what individuals choose to do, approving of some choices and disapproving of others. This ethical background is enmeshed with the dominant religious and philosophical traditions within a culture at a particular point in time.

Subject: Religion and Society
ContentDescription: Today, religious and philosophical traditions interact with other sources of authority and moral values represented in the media and popular culture. Nevertheless, society still often relies on cultural heritages that contain a variety of ethical perspectives as well as values centred on human dignity and basic justice. These perspectives and values remain fundamental to many legal and social systems, and to codes of behaviour. They constitute the everyday categories of ethical discourse in the world. They are taken by the individuals and groups that hold them to be the starting point and common ground for discussion about ethical issues and moral behaviour in societies where multiple worldviews coexist.

Subject: Religion and Society
ContentDescription: In this unit students study in detail various methods of ethical decision-making in at least two religious traditions and their related philosophical traditions. They explore ethical issues in societies where multiple worldviews coexist, in the light of these investigations.

Subject: Religion and Society
ContentDescription: Students consider the aspects of religion on page 10 when exploring selected religious traditions and religion in general.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethical decision-making and moral judgment
ContentDescription: In this area of study students are introduced to the nature of ethical decision-making in societies where multiple worldviews coexist.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethical decision-making and moral judgment
Elaboration: Ethical decision-making involves the selection of methods that have guiding concepts, principles and theories.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethical decision-making and moral judgment
Elaboration: Students explore concepts that underpin ethical decision-making and influences on practical moral judgment.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethical decision-making and moral judgment
ContentDescription: Methods of ethical decision-making such as ‘ought’ ethics, virtue ethics, character ethics and outcome ethics are discussed, as well as theories leading to and derived from these methods.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethical decision-making and moral judgment
Elaboration: These methods and their supporting theories are based on various sources of ethical authority, such as divine command.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethical decision-making and moral judgment
Elaboration: Ethical methods and practical moral judgment are subject to varying emphases on factors such as absolutism, anarchy, anomie, circumstances, divinity, duties, emotionalism, fear, institutions, laws (secular and religious), love, mandates, natural law, outcomes, poetic justice, pragmatism, reason, relativism, stakeholders, scientism, social justice, social order and social norms, subjectivism, the common good and tradition.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethical decision-making and moral judgment
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to explain the variety of influences on ethical decision-making and moral judgment in societies where multiple worldviews coexist.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethical decision-making and moral judgment
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 1.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Religion and ethics
ContentDescription: In this area of study students explore religious ethical perspectives and other influences on the formation of moral judgments of at least two spiritualities, religious traditions and/or religious denominations, in societies where multiple worldviews coexist.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Religion and ethics
Elaboration: They also explore how philosophical ideas and religion have influenced each other’s understanding of ethics.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Religion and ethics
Elaboration: Certain authorities, values, norms, ideas and ethical principles inform broad ethical perspectives and moral judgments within religious and philosophical traditions.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Religion and ethics
Elaboration: Other aspects of religion – in particular beliefs, texts and sacred stories – inform the decision-making process for religious traditions.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Religion and ethics
ContentDescription:
On completion of this unit the student should be able to analyse how ethical perspectives and moral judgments are formed within at least two spiritualities, religious traditions and/or religious denominations, in 
societies in which multiple worldviews coexist.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Religion and ethics
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 2.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Ethical issues in society
ContentDescription: In this area of study students build on the knowledge explored in Areas of Study 1 and 2.

Elaboration:
Focusing on two 
or more ethical issues, students apply this knowledge to an examination of debates about ethical issues conducted in the public arena of societies in which multiple religious and non-religious worldviews coexist.

Subject: Religion and Society

Elaboration: The analysis should explain why the issue is regarded as an ethical issue; identify contributors to the debate, including spiritualities, religious traditions or religious denominations; consider the influence of participants’ contributions; and investigate the basis of ethical perspectives and moral judgments used in the debates, including the ethical methods involved in the decision-making process.

ContentDescription:
On completion of this unit the student should be able to examine two or more debates on ethical issues 
in societies in which multiple worldviews coexist, and to which spiritualities, religious traditions and religious denominations contribute.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Ethical issues in society
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 3.

Subject: Religion and Society
ContentDescription: Over time and across cultures humanity has sought to understand the why and how of existence. In this quest for meaning humans have consistently posed big questions of life such as: Where did we come from? Is there someone or something greater than us - an ultimate reality? What is the purpose of our existence? How should we live? Is there anything beyond death? In response to this search for meaning, various spiritual, religious, philosophical, scientific and ideological worldviews have been developed. Religion has developed answers in the form of a truth narrative: various beliefs and other aspects that have offered ways of establishing meaning, not only for human existence but also for all that exists. The aspects of religion also attempt to express and explain the nature of relationships between humans individually and collectively, between humans and ultimate reality and between humans and the rest of the natural world.

Subject: Religion and Society
ContentDescription: The beliefs of religion are the ideas held about ultimate reality and the meaning of human existence, such as the purpose of all life and notions of the afterlife. These beliefs, together with their expressions through the other aspects, form the distinctive identity of a religious tradition or religious denomination.

Subject: Religion and Society
ContentDescription: In this unit students study the purposes of religion generally and then consider the religious beliefs developed by a religious tradition or religious denomination in response to the big questions of life. Students study how particular beliefs within a religious tradition or religious denomination may be expressed through the other aspects of religion, and explore how this is intended to foster meaning for adherents. Students then consider the interaction between significant life experiences and religion.

Subject: Religion and Society
ContentDescription: Religious traditions or religious denominations are to be selected from Buddhism, Christianity, Hinduism, Islam, Judaism and Sikhism.

Subject: Religion and Society
ContentDescription: Students consider the aspects of religion on page 10 when investigating religion in general and selected religious traditions or religious denominations.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Responding to the search for meaning
ContentHeader: Responding to the search for meaning
ContentDescription: In this area of study students are introduced to the nature and purpose of religion in the human search for meaning.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Responding to the search for meaning

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Responding to the search for meaning
ContentHeader: Responding to the search for meaning
Elaboration: Students are introduced to the purpose of religion in societies in which multiple worldviews coexist through the study in detail of a range of beliefs of one religious tradition or religious denomination.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Responding to the search for meaning
ContentHeader: Responding to the search for meaning
Elaboration: Religious beliefs are ideas that answer the big questions of life according to a religious worldview.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Responding to the search for meaning
ContentHeader: Responding to the search for meaning
Elaboration: In this area of study students relate the beliefs to certain categories and explore the connection of the beliefs to each other.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Responding to the search for meaning

ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to analyse the nature and purpose of religion and religious beliefs.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Responding to the search for meaning

ContentDescription: In this area of study students build on the knowledge of religious beliefs from Area of Study 1.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Expressing meaning
Elaboration: Beliefs are intended to achieve their full meaning when they are expressed through other aspects of religion.

Elaboration: Students study how the meaning of beliefs are expressed through other aspects of religion.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Expressing meaning
Elaboration: They consider the roles of the aspects of religion in general.

Elaboration: Students then explore at least two beliefs studied in Area of Study 1, as they are expressed in other aspects of the selected religious tradition or religious denomination.

Subject: Religion and Society

Elaboration: They examine how the selected beliefs and their expression in each of the other aspects are intended by the selected religious tradition or religious denomination to support meaning.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Expressing meaning
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to examine how beliefs and their expression through other aspects of religion are intended to respond to the search for meaning.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Expressing meaning
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 2.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Significant life experiences, religious beliefs and faith
ContentHeader: Significant life experiences, religious beliefs and faith
ContentDescription: In this area of study students focus on the interplay between religion and significant life experiences of members of religious traditions and religious denominations.

Subject: Religion and Society

ContentHeader: Significant life experiences, religious beliefs and faith
Elaboration: Students consider the relationship between different types of significant life experiences and religious beliefs generally.

Subject: Religion and Society

ContentHeader: Significant life experiences, religious beliefs and faith
Elaboration: They then undertake a detailed study of one particular significant life experience of a member of one selected religious tradition or religious denomination.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Significant life experiences, religious beliefs and faith
ContentHeader: Significant life experiences, religious beliefs and faith
Elaboration: The significant life experience may be a single event at a particular time or occur over an extended period.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Significant life experiences, religious beliefs and faith
ContentHeader: Significant life experiences, religious beliefs and faith
Elaboration: It has to be an experience that informed, reinforced or changed the person’s faith in and understanding of beliefs and their engagement with the expression of those beliefs.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Significant life experiences, religious beliefs and faith
ContentHeader: Significant life experiences, religious beliefs and faith
Elaboration: Students investigate what happens to an individual’s adherence to and understanding of the relevant religious beliefs and related expressions in the other aspects as a result of a significant life experience.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Significant life experiences, religious beliefs and faith
ContentHeader: Significant life experiences, religious beliefs and faith
ContentDescription: The person and experience studied must have been published in publicly accessible documentary, biographical or autobiographical non-fictional material.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Significant life experiences, religious beliefs and faith
ContentHeader: Significant life experiences, religious beliefs and faith
Elaboration:
The source(s) must provide detailed commentary 
on the interaction of the related beliefs, and their expression in other aspects, to the member of the religious tradition’s significant life experience.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Significant life experiences, religious beliefs and faith
ContentHeader: Significant life experiences, religious beliefs and faith
Elaboration: The person must be a member of a religious tradition and the significant life experience cannot be one of conversion from one religious tradition or religious denomination to another.

ContentHeader: Significant life experiences, religious beliefs and faith
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to analyse the interplay between religious beliefs and their expression through related aspects of religion and significant life experiences.

ContentHeader: Significant life experiences, religious beliefs and faith

Subject: Religion and Society
ContentDescription: This unit focuses on the interaction over time of religious traditions and religious denominations and the societies of which they are a part. For a large part of human history religion has been drawn on as a truth narrative, offering a means for finding answers to the big questions of life. Religious traditions and religious denominations are in a dynamic process of engagement and negotiation with members individually and collectively, as well as with other key institutions in wider society associated with power, authority and credibility. Religious traditions and religious denominations are living institutions that interact with society and can likewise be influenced by society. They can stimulate and support society, acting as levers for change themselves and embracing or resisting forces for change within society.

Subject: Religion and Society
ContentDescription: Religious traditions and religious denominations are in a constant state of development as members apply their talents and faith to extend the intellectual and aesthetic nature of a tradition's or denomination's beliefs, of the expression of these beliefs and of the application of these beliefs to their lives. Opportunities for development also come from significant challenges in the interaction of religious traditions and religious denominations and society, including the needs and insights of their members and other people and groups within wider society. A challenge is a situation that stimulates a response from society and/or religious traditions and religious denominations. These challenges and the religious tradition and religious denomination are influenced by broader contexts such as changing economic and environmental conditions, and political, social or technological developments.

Subject: Religion and Society
ContentDescription: Religious traditions and religious denominations can take stances for or against challenges, or they can take a stance of indifference. Consequently, actions that involve different aspects of the religious tradition or religious denomination are implemented. These actions may resist or embrace change and affect wider society and/or the religious tradition or religious denomination itself. A key aim beyond resolution of the challenge itself is for religious traditions to retain integrity, authenticity, authority, adherents and, ultimately, identity. However, the interaction between religious traditions and religious denominations and society may not always achieve these aims and there may be a series of interactions as a challenge is negotiated.

Subject: Religion and Society
ContentDescription: In this unit students explore challenges for religious traditions or religious denominations generally over time and then undertake a study of challenge and change for a religious tradition or religious denomination.

Subject: Religion and Society
ContentDescription: Religious traditions or religious denominations are to be selected from Buddhism, Christianity, Hinduism, Islam, Judaism and Sikhism.

Subject: Religion and Society
ContentDescription: Students consider the aspects of religion on page 10 in their investigation of selected religious tradition(s) or religious denomination(s) and religion in general.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Challenge and response
ContentDescription: In this area of study students investigate how and why religious traditions and religious denominations have taken steps from their inception to the present to respond to challenges in the categories of theology, ethics and continued existence.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Challenge and response
ContentDescription: Religious traditions or their denominations are in a continual process of engagement and negotiation with challenges that may influence them to adopt various stances for, against or of indifference to the challenge.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Challenge and response
Elaboration: A stance is a principled perspective, and a stance may be expressed in various responses that support the stance, including not responding in any practical or discernible way.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Challenge and response
Elaboration: A stance can itself be enough to respond to the challenge and to retain integrity, authenticity, authority and identity for the religious tradition’s or religious denomination’s leadership and adherents.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Challenge and response
Elaboration: With various stances there will be a mixture of supporting responses that attempt to bring about change or attempt to retain the status quo, though these may not always accomplish the desired results.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Challenge and response
ContentDescription: The impetus for religious traditions or religious denominations to take a stance can come from a variety of sources.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Challenge and response
Elaboration: The ability of a religious tradition or religious denomination to adopt different stances is variously determined by beliefs, authority structures, official teachings, rulings of religious law, tradition, key individuals and attitudes within the religious and wider communities.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Challenge and response
ContentDescription: Students consider how some aspects of one religious tradition or religious denomination are more likely to be involved when taking a stance, such as distinctive beliefs, rituals, religious practices, the interpretation of texts, the application of ethical principles, the nature and role of authority, and the manner of participation within the social structure of a religious tradition or religious denomination.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Challenge and response
Elaboration: They develop an overview of challenges to the religious tradition or religious denomination.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Challenge and response
Elaboration: Three significant challenges are selected, and the stances and supporting responses taken by the religious tradition or religious denomination are studied.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Challenge and response
Elaboration: Each of the selected challenges should encompass one or more of the categories of theology, ethics and continued existence, but the student’s study as a whole should cover all categories.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Challenge and response
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to analyse and compare stances and supporting responses taken by religious traditions or religious denominations as they are challenged.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Challenge and response
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 1.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interaction of religion and society
ContentDescription: Students examine in detail one significant challenge that has engaged or continues to engage a religious tradition or religious denomination and society.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interaction of religion and society
ContentDescription: Religious traditions and religious denominations are in a continual interactive process of engagement and negotiation with their members and with the trends, ideas, events and innovations found in wider society or within the religious tradition or religious denomination that can affect one or more aspects of religion and form the broader context of a challenge.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interaction of religion and society
Elaboration: Specific people or groups in a religious tradition or religious denomination, and/or in wider society, may advocate for supporting, resisting or taking no discernible action in response to the challenge.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interaction of religion and society
Elaboration: The sources of challenges influence religious traditions and religious denominations to adopt stances for support, resistance or indifference to the challenge.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interaction of religion and society
Elaboration: Stances and supporting responses to the challenge may vary as interactions continue throughout the challenge, and the results may or may not produce the desired effects.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interaction of religion and society
ContentDescription:
The selected challenge may be related to a particular time in the past or present of the religious tradition 
or religious denomination.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interaction of religion and society
Elaboration: It may be a challenge that has recurred and is then studied over a period of time.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interaction of religion and society
Elaboration: The selected challenge may have occurred in the past but the responses may be ongoing and the resolution may not yet have been achieved in the present day.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interaction of religion and society
Elaboration: Responses may involve advocacy and/or reaction by the religious tradition or religious denomination at various times.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interaction of religion and society
ContentDescription: The challenge should be at a stage where a range of analyses of the influence of the responses have been made by commentators, thus enabling the student to use primary and secondary source material.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interaction of religion and society
Elaboration: The challenge should be different from the challenges studied in Area of Study 1.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interaction of religion and society
ContentDescription: Students investigate the broader context leading to the challenge, the sources of the challenge, relevant aspects of religion, and the stances and supporting responses adopted by the religious tradition or religious denomination to the challenge.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interaction of religion and society
Elaboration: They also examine the influence of the responses on the religious tradition or religious denomination and, where appropriate, on wider society.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interaction of religion and society
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to discuss the interactions within a religious tradition or religious denomination and between a religious tradition or religious denomination and wider society in relation to a significant challenge, and evaluate the influence of the stances and responses on these interactions.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interaction of religion and society
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 2.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interaction of religion and society
ContentDescription: The examination will be set by a panel appointed by the VCAA.

Subject: Religion and Society
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Interaction of religion and society
Elaboration: All the key knowledge and key skills that underpin the outcomes in Units 3 and 4 are examinable.

ContentDescription: Duration: 2 hours
